messages.subject: [nihontostudy] Toppei koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, Just wanted folks to see an example that was different than the norm we typically see from Higo and Shonai. P.S. I was amused to see the one you recalled
messages.messageBody:
Tom,
Just wanted folks to see an example that was different
than the norm we typically see from Higo and Shonai.

P.S. I was amused to see the one you recalled
in Ginza Choshuya as late as March when I was there.
Priced at 850,000 JPY. Koshirae only.
I had sold the piece (with katana attributed
to Owari Seki) about 8 yrs. ago at a sword show
to a Japanese dealer. Small world.

Regards,
Cary Condell

Condell & Co., Ltd.
P.O. Box 590115
San Francisco, CA 94159

Tel. 415-751-3784

condell@...
http://www.ikkyudo.com



tom helm wrote:
> Very nice Cary,
> and a bargain at that price, but dare I say it a bit garish
> even for me! I much prefer your OTHER Toppei which I think is
> exemplary of the style.
> -Tom

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Toppei koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: Very nice Cary, and a bargain at that price, but dare I say it a bit garish even for me! I much prefer your OTHER Toppei which I think is exemplary of the
messages.messageBody:
Very nice Cary,
and a bargain at that price, but dare I say it a bit garish
even for me! I much prefer your OTHER Toppei which I think is
exemplary of the style.
-Tom

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Toppei koshirae
messages.msgSnippet: This koshirae was the cause of a lot of enjoyment at the New York shinsa and, as Cary notes, got top numbers. A very class act. And the blade ain t too shabby
messages.messageBody:
This koshirae was the cause of a lot of enjoyment at the New York shinsa
and, as Cary notes, got top numbers. A very class act. And the blade ain't
too shabby either.

Gordon
-----Original Message-----
From: Cary Condell [mailto:condell@...]
Sent: Tuesday, June 17, 2003 5:46 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Toppei koshirae


Tom,
Try this one on for size:
http://www.ikkyudo.com/galleries/token/katana_9.htm

tom helm wrote:
> Jim et al-
> While I dig this style of Koshirae very much, I can't say I
> know all I would like to about them. Toppei I believe refers to the
> shape of the kashira and kojiri IE; tapering. I agree with all that
> Jim has said, I believe these were popular at the tail end of the Edo
> period when Western weapons and tactics were being fervently studied
> by the Japanese.
> This style of koshirae could be used with hakama or European
> trousers, hence the swivel often seen. The swivelling "kurikata"
> allowed the sword to be thrust thru the Obi or slung "backward" in
> western fashion when dressed in pants.
> The gunto koshirae is an extension of this idea and one can
> see how many different ways were invented to allow quick conversion
> from saber to uchigatana...
> More often than not these are of superior workmanship. My
> belief is that the new officers of the newly formed rifle or
> artillery units went for this style and most of them with the money
> to get a special set up like this were likely sons of the Bakufu.
> There is one memorable example of this style which is decidedly
> common, showing rough simple work suitable more for a foot soldier
> than an officer; That would be Saigo Takamoris' shuzaya toppei
> goshirae which carried a gimei Muramasa blade.
> I think this little tanto exhibits all the features of a
> quality koshirae in this style. There is one more feature not yet
> mentioned and that is that Toppei koshirae typically feature iron
> fittings with silver inlay (sometimes gold).
> That really is all I know (or have been taught). Thirsting for
more,
> Tom



Cary Condell

Condell & Co., Ltd.
P.O. Box 590115
San Francisco, CA 94159

Tel. 415-751-3784

condell@...
http://www.ikkyudo.com

> This style of koshirae could be used with hakama or European
> trousers, hence the swivel often seen. The swivelling "kurikata"
> allowed the sword to be thrust thru the Obi or slung "backward" in

> The gunto koshirae is an extension of this idea and one can
> see how many different ways were invented to allow quick conversion

> More often than not these are of superior workmanship. My
> belief is that the new officers of the newly formed rifle or
